byline.original: By NICOLE PERLROTH and KATIE BENNER

abstract: Encryption app maker Open Whisper Systems joins Microsoft and other tech firms criticizing Justice Dept for using excessive tactics to get user data; companies find particularly worrisome non-expiring, court-appointed gag orders, which prevents them from notifying customers government is subpoenaing their data; with help from American Civil Liberties Union, Open Whisper Systems was able to get part of its gag order lifted, but is still not allowed to tell certain account holders they are under investigation.

headline.print_headline: Federal Tactics in Data Pursuit Are Excessive, Tech Firms Say
headline.main: Subpoenas and Gag Orders Show Government Overreach, Tech Companies Argue

snippet: Open Whisper Systems received a subpoena for information on its Signal app subscribers and an order not to talk about it, a practice Microsoft and others say is too prevalent, and unconstitutional....
lead_paragraph: Open Whisper Systems received a subpoena for information on its Signal app subscribers and an order not to talk about it, a practice Microsoft and others say is too prevalent, and unconstitutional.
